Pecans scraped out of copper cans, and a natural cocoa powdered flavor over a bran flake conjecture.  Achieves the epitome of balance - full-bodied, tamed and natural carbonation, and the best backdrop of subtle, spicy hops to accompany a resplendent stream of liquid wonderment.  This is easily the prototype of doppelbocks.

Bottle @ Spuyten Duyvil for the bock night last monday.  Pours a nice bright ruby red, deep amber, thcik lasting tan head and good lace.  Aroma is very bready and malty, but not as sweet as expected, but still very intense with tons of lighter munich malts.  Toasted bready flavors with light caramel, nutty, melanoidins in the middle for more sweetness and body, and some mollasses.  Smooth as silk, and not too thick like some doppelbocks.  This is probably the best doppelbock I have ever had, and is a classic example of the style.  Asam Bock gets a close second.

Bottle at Spuyten Duyvil.  Caramel brown color with a creamy tan head.  Great head retention.  Hints of brown sugar, caramel, currant, raisin, chocolate, molasses and coffee.  Very pleasant and creamy taste.  The caramel and currant worked very well together and intensified as it went down.  Awesome beer.  I wish it were more avaliable in the states.

Bottled. Beer #1000 and a cracker it was.  Body a deep polished browm, billowing head that collapses to slick wisps, light roast notes and ripe fruits to the nose. Then the sweetshop medley; quality liqourice, Scottish caramel, sugar almonds, honeycomb. An assertive malt finish. 

Heres hoping I can find a beer this good for #2000  :)

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2006 RERATE:  Bottle shared with joss and Oakes.  Dark brown thich pale amber/tan head.  Sweet malty aroma, clean fresh and bready dark toasted malt.  Really clean tasting.  Chewy, but not super sweet.  Toasty with a hint of caramelized and almost smoky sweetness.  Really well-balanced and better than I though the first time around.

Bottle shared with beastiefan2k and dickinsonbeer at Spuyten Duyvil.  Clear deep garnet beer with a thin white head.  Great bread crust, crackery/biscuity malt character.  There is some light plumminess there as well along with some clean but aromatic noble hops.  Body is nicely balanced, has a bit of peppery alcohol bite, but there is still enough maltiness to balance.  Some nutty and slightly oxidized aromas seem to be in here.  Flavour is balanced.  Its a tasty enough brew, but not all that special either.

Ar 7 Ap 3 Fl 7 Pa 3 Ov 12

(Bottle (best by 12/29/05) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 target=blank>beeryum, thanks Dave!) Dark honey-brown body with a half-inch of soft biscuit head. Aroma is fairly mild - honey and malt sweetness. Only very slight lacing. Mouthfeel is very smooth but actually fairly light-bodied. Flavor is honey and malty sweetness overlain by light bitterness. Leaves a honey aftertaste. Nice stuff but thought thered be more - pretty flavorful but not really complex. Slight alcohol apparency in finish. Honeyish flavor and smoothness were probably most notable qualities.
Draught at Klosterbrauerei Andechs. Brownish colour with a light brown head. Aroma and taste of fruits and malts. Very good dobbelbock.

Draught af Klosterbrauerei Andechs.
Creamy white good mostly lasting head. red-brown colour. Powerfull aroma and fantastic caramellic flavor. Long powerfull finish. Very oily palate. A very good beer.

Bottle thanks to Papsoe.  Pours deep reddish brown with a big off-white head that fades pretty quickly to some sirrus clouds.  Nice malty aroma.  Taste is sweet at first, with the malts dominating.  At the end, it has an unusual bitterness that sufaces along the sweetness, not replacing it.  Its very interesting and drinkable.
An aroma of barley and malt introduce this beer.  It is brown with a white head.  This beer has a mild chocolate grain taste.  It fades smooth leaving a mild chocolate nut/malt taste lingering.

Brought back from the old country by Brian. Thanks! Sampled at the Fat Tuesday tasting with friends. Enjoyed it, but it did not blow me away by any means. But for the price of less than a Euro, one cant go wrong. Pours a good mahogany brown with banana, clove, and caramel coming through on the nose. Leads int a solid malted beer, with some doppelbock funk. If I had the choice, Id turn to Capitals Doppelbock series over this one. Tasty, but not overwhelming by any stretch.

A dark, reddish brown beer with a strong white head. A very sweet, toasted malt nose with a hint of citrus fruit, the finish is slightly bitter sweet, similar to liquorice. The taste again is sweet malt, a potent, slightly alcoholic flavour comes though towards the end, with a long, lingering malty aftertaste. Bottle, purchased from the Beers of Europe, Setchey, Norfolk.

There is something joyful about a good Dopplebock. Right off the first taste I am reminded of an enjoyable trip to Idaho that involved some Optimators on tap. Dark brown mahogany beer with thick foam that leaves behind a wisp of lacing. Not a strong aroma but I get a roasted nut scent with some alcohol or nut oil. Palate is a bit oily and thick. Just enough alcohol taste to be welcomed but not obnoxious. Flavour is brown sugar, funky wood and alcohol. Not overly complex just very good. Thank you Papsoe!

Courtesy of Pialhead. Clear mahogany with off-white head. Aroma all roasted garin with the faintest caramel malt background. Flavor is dominated by the roasted grain, borders on burnt grain. Buttery nut finish. Tad dissapointed. This had been on my want list forever, hope to get a chance to re-rate this in the future.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2013 Very clear and clean looking dark brown and deep rose red colored body.  Nose is sweet cherries and plums and brown sugar with some cedar wood notes.  Very full and rich on the palate, surprisingly thick and robust.  Tastes of wood and very subtle black cherries, some very light char on the back of the tongue and in the finish.  Overall quite sweet up front with a more rounded and almost rough texture on the back of the tongue.   Has an acidic and bitter note to it as well, making an interesting transition from the sweetness noticed up front.  Worthy of praise.

Bottle:  Courtesy of beeryum via trade.  Aroma has lots of roasted grain and nuttiness with some hints of brown sugar.  Pours a bright transparent red with a small off-white head.  Flavors of brown sugar, caramel, and tofee up front.  Some graininess in the the middle.  Lots of nuttiness in the finish.  Suprised by the overall score of this one.

Thanks styles. Poured a reddish brown with a thin white head. Aroma was roasty with brown surgar and grainy. flavors were malty with hints of toffee and light chocolate. I think the best part of this beer is the finish that was creamy and malty.

Kloster Andechs is a monastery on top of a mountain that sits in the shadow of the Bavarian Alps. The monastery grounds are absolutely beautiful and is surrounded by rich farm land which is owned and worked by the Kloster. Why Andechs is important to a beer lover, is the fact that the Benedictine monks that established this Kloster, also established a brewery in 1455. The Rule of St. Benedict is, as a monk, you have to live by the work of your hands. The work these monks do at Andechs is the brewing some of the most incredible beer on the planet. I have tasted thousands of beers in my life time as a beer drinker, and Andechs Dopplebock Dunkel could possibly be the best beer I have ever tasted in all my years of drinking. It is most certainly the most impressive dopple bock I have ever tried, and drinking a one liter mass of this beer fresh vom fass was a spiritual experience for me. 

Andechs Dopplebock Dunkel pours to a beautiful, bright, chestnut color with a thick and creamy tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is wonderful with deep toasty, nutty and sweet malty aromas. This leads in to a sweet malty, toasty, and nutty palate on a round, smooth, clean, and polished body. Andechs Dopplebock Dunkel finishes with more deep malt character up front, then ends with just enough hop bitterness to take the cloying edge off this beer. There is also a nice subtle, peppery alcohol burn that lingers with flavors of malt on the tongue. 

Stylistically this beer is flawless. As a dopple bock it is perfect. It is a master piece of the brewers art. Ive had some tremendous dopple bocks in my day, but I am yet to taste one that is better than this beer. I can not put into words the depth of malt aromas and flavors in this beer, and how fantastic this beer really is. You will just have to come to Germany to try this one for yourself, as it is not exported to the US. I was fortunate enough to enjoy 2 liters of this one on a wonderful trip to Andechs, and encourage anyone who is going to Bavaria to take a day trip out to the Kloster.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2006 Dark brown with a nice creamy head. Malty aroma (a bit of barn too) with some sweet brown sugar. Flavor is also very malty. It is full-bodied, but very sweet! - rum... Alcohol is not too dominant.

Thanks to Secret Santa for this one.  It poured deep brownish-ruby with 2-finger off-white head.  The aroma was nutty and malty with some corn flakeyness and brown sugar.  The flavor was very malty, with the Wheaties, brown sugar, and some figgy notes.  Well balanced and complex.  I had this one with a CAO Brazilia cigar on New Years Eve.

Clear deep red with a big creamy tan coloured head. Aroma is rich and malty and the flavour is wonderfull, slightly smokey, malty and delicious.
Bottle bought from Manchesters German Xmas market.....cant wait for this Xmas ill buy loads.

Bottle.  Darker brown pour with a good head.  Fairly rich malty caramel aroma and some toffee too.  More rich caramel malty flavors and a touch of some lighter apple fruit notes and a touch of toffee and chocolate and nuts.  Drinks smooth and a nice mouthfeel.  Very nice.

Enough abundant and creamy head, good persistence. Burnt brown color, much dark and little fizzy one. Complex and alcoholic scent; braced malty notes, burn wood and liqueur, extremely bitter. Enough dry and arid taste, light notes of licorice surpassed from an overbearing and persistent bitter. Also notes of burnt caramel, ash and alcohol. Medium along final.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2012 [Re-rate]Bottled.  One of my favorites, even after 1K.  Beige head, brown/red pour, simply beautiful to look at.  Sweet malty nose with dark fruits and a touch of roast.  Sweet roasted/toasty beginning, dark fruits and berry finish.  Some light caramel notes and slightly stronger cherry.  Alcohol is well-integrated and barely warming.  Smooth, soft mouthful with a medium-full body.  Is that chocolate I taste at the bottom of the glass?  A flavorful and very complex brew -- Scandalously good. [4.5][12/31/2005]Well, Ive lived the dream and had a few dozen bottles over the years, and even visited Andechs this past week.  Im happy to report this has become relatively easy to find in Germany, especially Berlin and Munich, though there are definitely bad bottles to be had here and there (are these things connected?).  But without a doubt, the bottles hit quite often (my current one has some nice smoke undertones and light peach groaning under the weight of cherry), and the tap experience can be utterly sublime  -- cherry dominance to rival a kriek, plums to match the best quads, lightly spicy hops and some of the best malt depth in central Europe.  No plans for an Andechs tattoo, but the idea has been considered.... [25 July 2012]

Brown, some tan head. Nose is malts, toffee, some light yeasty notes. Wonderful texture, very smooth and easygoing. Taste is lots of sweet caramel malt and some bread notes. Just a shade below Celebrator, but very good nonetheless.

500ml bottle from Madsberg shared with JoshuaB. Pours a brown nutty color with a light white head. Nose is malty, caramel, nutty. very well balanced and one of the easiest beers to drink Ive ever had.
A good doppelbock. At the beginning a bit tasteless. But the taste grows and at last is almost delicious.

Yes this is a good beer. Aroma hit me when i opened the bottle of coffee, but thankfully this faded away, moving onto malt  sweet notes, mainly caramel, however in a better than normal way. Taste is excellent everythign good about a dunkel, lightly burnt bittering malts with a great sweetness, backed with a slight warming from the alcohol. Such an excellent brew that i would love to try again.

Damn! What a gorgeous brew!Tan two fingered head that lives long and large. Lace is, well, very lacey and sticky. All this atop a lovely clear brown body accented by a deep ruby red glow. Nose of malt, freshly milled grains, bread thats lightly toasted, very nice indeed. Body is medium, soft textured, loving on yer tongue. Lightly sweet malts are grainy with notes of dark fruits, chocolate, caramel and light toffee notes, a malt lovers dream! Finish is lightly sweet, caramelly. A well rounded representation. I,ve looked forward to sampling this brew since i,ve been on RB. It has proven itself to me! Thanks go out to Springslicker for this one! Thanks Jay!!
Beautiful deep garnet in color, sweet malts and an almost angel food cake nose.  Rich and mouth filling, a maltyness that is long lingering and sweet with a nice hop balance.

Bottle courtesy of thedm and hotstuff at Indy tasting.  Clear brown with brassy colors.  Aroma is malty and also with  a fruity cider like character.  Very roasted, toasted, and a bit fruity in the flavor.  Chocolate malts and carmel smoothness.  Very plesant beer.

(Bottle courtesy the_dm Indy tasting 12/10/05) - 2005 - Aroma of carmel, toffee, malt, and black licorice.  Pours a deep brownish red with medium head.  Flavor is sweet creamy carmel and chocolate malts with subtle hop undertones.  Palate is very smooth and clean.  A great Doppelbock.

bottle courtesy of the dm at the indy tasting. amber brown pour with a great grey head. aroma of booze, caramel, light chocolate. dusted chocolate flavor with some nice tea notes. love the caramel, christwagons, this is good. marshmallow mouthfeel. thanks again, matt.

Bottle.  Thanks to THEDM for sharing this.  Pours a redish brown color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is light with apple cider notes.  Flavor produces complex chocolate and coffee notes.  Huge creamy mouthfeel.  Excellent brew.

On tap at the Kloster in a 1L stein.  Deep brown reddish color.  Thick mouth feel with a malty body that has many different flavors in it.  Towards the end of liter you start tasting more boozy flavors that warm you on a cold late november Bavarian day.
50 cl bottle. No yeast in bottom. Reddish brown colour with a very nice beige head. Sweet malty aroma also sweet malty flavour with hints of caramel. Ends up light and refreshing.

50 cl bottel
Color - Dark red/brown
Head - Beige
Aroma - Sweet, malty
Flavor - Sweet, malty
ok beer

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2011 Hearty rounded deep warm tones of rich dark malts and smooth alcohol, taste rich rark dried fruits with and edge of spiciness from the perfectly dry but not imposing hops. Fantastisch!
UPDATED: OCT 15, 2013 Brown with a little head. Malt, bread, dried fruit and red apple aromas. Somewhat sweet but with enough hops to balance. Very warming.

European Bottle Pour (Duh) - Deep brown body with light brown head. Aroma - Coffee, dark chocolate, malty, a bit fruity, quite sweet. Flavor - More chocolate and coffee, a little smokey. Full body with creamy palate. Finishes on the slightly bitter side. Delicious...

Best before 12/30/05. Very dark brown with ruby hues on the edges. Dense, bubbly, off white head. Aroma of roasty malt, smoke, chocoffee, dark fruits-figs. Same flavor, medium body, dry and smokey, bubbly yet creamy. Roasty aftertaste. One of if not the best dopplebocks Ive had.
Poured a golden brown with a small cream colored head.  Aroma of dark fruit but light   Very fruity flavor with some sweet chocolate mixed in.  Dry and warming finish.

I had it at the Andechs Monestary, along with their wonderful food.  Out of the tap with a rich head and a large dimpled mug, the aroma was wonderful.  A wonderfully lively beer with a very complex finish and a smooth maltiness.  Very quinching, and firm but not over-filling, as I was able to down about three liters in an afternoon.  Possibly the best beer experience of my life.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours ruby-brown with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavour are mainly malt with notes of alcohol, smoke and a bit of sourness. Im not a huge Bunkel fan (thanks tupalev!) but this is pretty good.

Bottle, shared with Blankboy, GregClow, and HogTownHarry, courtesy of my wifes adventurous bosses in Switzerland.  Dark ruby red, very thin white head.  Some alcohol, some sweet malt, hint of smoke in aroma.  Very solid malt taste, medium body, bubbly mouthfeel.  Neat smoky sweet finish.  Doesnt knock your socks off, but this is a very solid bock/dunkel (we coined the phrase Bunkel, which fits here I think).  7.1%? Really?

Intense bold flavour, bit of everything.  Roast, whiff of smoke, some sourness, dark chocolate, molasses. Medium-full chewy mouthful.  Dark chocolate colour, chocolate aroma.  Creaminess and really interesting range of flavours with multi-course meal. Thanks Mr. Madsberg from Denmark.

Bottle from some bottle shop in Switzerland, courtesy of tupalev - shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry and tupalev. Ruby-brown colour with a small mocha head. Aroma is very malty and earthy, with a pleasant hint of smoke that develops nicely as it warms. Flavour is very roasty, with notes of coffee and mild molasses, and more of that lovely smokiness. Really nice stuff - thanks for sharing, Jeff!

Bottle (from Bitter Virtue, BBE Feb 06). There were some really nice flavours in this - liqourice, choc, nuts, plenty of malt and an earthy back drop. The agressive carbonation and thin body really spoiled this for me although it was still mighty drinkable considering the strength which wasnt at all noticeable.

Bottle (500ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow and Tupalev, bottle courtesy of tupalev - with the aid of a super-secret Canadian/Scottish agency in Switzerland. Poured clear ruby-amber with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of sour roast malt, fungi, plent of bitter hops, smoke - overall a surprisingly dark, funky earthy-peaty beer for a bock, almost a rauchbier to my nose.  Taste follows the aroma, sweet roasted malt and balancing hops, but the smoke asserts itself and really grows on you; the alcohol finally makes its presence felt as it warms and opens up.  Good thickish body, a bit slick.  I really want to try this one again, savour it - good stuff.

(500ml, best by 2/18/06) Clear copper body topped by big beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, nutty, caramel, some cherry, light bread, herbal.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, cherry, some alcohol, herbal, light molasses.  Some nuttiness and chocolate appear as the beer warms.  Smooth medium body.  Seems a bit light for a doppel -- more like the bocks I have had.  Good stuff, but the alcohol shone through a bit too much for me to embrace it to the level that others have.

[bottle from beers of europe] Pours very dark brown with a dense tan head. Aroma is hugely malty, chocolate, brown sugar, there are also some berry fruit aromas and a faint touch of roasted coffee. body is excellent, alcohol is very well conceiled, finish is silky soft.

Bottle, at home. Dark brown with light brown head, almost diminishing, fair lacings. Aroma heavy malty (bread, brown sugar) and moderate hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet with a moderate, long bitter duration. Body medium, oily, soft carbonated.

Saarlander sent this gem my way as part of our last trade, Thanks Aaron!  aroma of roasted malts, toffee, german chocolate and rye grain.  the look is outstanding with its deep chestnut brown body and a whipped, creamy tan head.  this has a wonderful balance to the flavor, toffee, chocolate, rye, and a slightly dry hop finish.  very smooth and slightly silky on the tongue.  light carbonation which is a big plus for me.  a superb beer, not only to the style, but to any style.

500 ml bottle, bought in Germany. ABV is 7.1%. Deep chestnut colour, large and creamy light tan head. Very nice roasty aroma with notes of rye bread, caramel, hints of liquorice and chocolate. Fairly dry roasty flavour (roast malts), notes of coffee, toast and rye bread. Dry and hoppy bitter finish. An excellent doppelbock, not as smooth and sweet as some others of this style.

Pours brownish red with a medium light tan that fades Aroma is of dough, dark caramel, some cinnamon, somewhat roasty, some chocolate, a slight alcoholic fume. Flavor is if coffee, bitter chocolate, dough, caramel. Bit of alcohol in the finish. Full bodied. Full yet smooth beer flavor and body wise.

Bottle. Okay - everybody seems to dig this. I just went against the grain on another Andechser beer and, although this is far better, Im still way below the average rating. Am I just drunk? Oh well...: Pours a dark brown colour with an off-white head. Sweetish and malty aroma. Fruity notes as well as notes of alcohol. Flavour is equally sweetish and malty. Overall just an average beer, in my opinion.

500ml. bottle dated 3/21/05 brought back from Germany by a friend. Brown/red color with a small tan head. Mildly sweet malty aroma with some dried fruits and nuts. Bready, malty flavor that is much drier than the aroma would have you believe. In fact the finish is bone dry. This may sound weird, but the flavor reminds me a wee bit of the beers from Westvleteren. I get that same bready, yeasty flavor. Very enjoyable.

Dark reddish brown colour with a big long-lasting tan coloured foam. Deep malty aroma of figs, blue plums, dark chocolate and black currant. Malty big flavour of figs, nuts, dark chocolate and raisin. Well masked alcohol. Long chocolately finish.
brownish orange color, lots of nuts and raisons and other dark fruits in it.  i think there is some chocolate too, this was another noogfest victim.

Bottle.  lucky find.  Found this in a German getrankmart after reviewing the top 50 on ratebeer.com.  I am glad I did.  This is a real stand out of the 50 or so beers offered at the store.  Many German beers have a similar taste and character, but this doppelbock is solid.  Aroma of almost chocolate, decent spicy wood and orange peel in the flavor.  This is a beer to share with friends, to keep on stock, and to enjoy.  One of the best so far Ive tasted in Germany.

My notes say "w..he/ ite" WTF??? Well I can read the rest of it. A reddish brown appearance. The flavor is rather sour with a red and white grape presence. I also detect some chocolate and raisins. A bit of alcohol shows in the finish. Good bier!
tastes decent enough.  i think i dont have a flavor for this quite yet.  hints of chocolate and hops weird citrus after taste

Another thanks to my roommate Skidz for bringing this back from Germany for me!  After the initial pour, it appeared to be a rather dark, murky brown, but when looking at the body through the light, after wiping away all of the condensation due to the cold glass and high humidity, it actually turns out to be a dark reddish amber, cola-like.  Nice, lasting head.  Nutty aroma, with light burnt caramel and brown sugar.Very full, slightly roasty flavor, heavy on very sweet malts.  Raisins as well.  I was surprised by the moderate hop presence.  A little too sticky sweet for my tastes.  Lastling light bitterness in the back of the mouth.  A great beer, but I think it would have been much more enjoyable on a day with less heat and humidity!  The syrupy sweetness bothered me a bit in my nearly sweltering apartment.

very nice but very sweet. aromas of molasses, toffee, caramel, maybe a bit malt(molasses?). taste is sweet,bit bitter, smoky, plums, raisins and other dark fruits also a bit of dark chocolate. mf is cloyingly sweet and sourish. finish is long, sweet and alcohol is present.

(Bottle 50 cl) Dark brown (almost cola-flavoured) with a huge, neat and lightly brownish head. Wonderful nutty nose and immensely full and malty aromas. Has some of the same flavour-patterns as Belgian trappists - although a higher bitterness. A great bock indeed. 201099

First of all, thanks Nat! 500ml bottle. Served at 53.5° (~12°C) in my NB worthy glass. Pours dark crimson red with a smallish off-white/nearly tan head. The beer coats the glass when swirled.  Aroma is sweet malt, milk chocolate, dark fruits, with hints of noble hops? The mouthfeel is full, but not overly so. The taste is malty with the noble hops? grassiness and spiciness. There are flavors of tofee, vanilla, prunes?, and pepper? The finish is slightly bitter and finishes clean. I havent had a dopplebock in a long while, but this seems a bit different from the ones I have had, there is less sweetness and fullness of body and more drinkability; it would be far too easy to spend an afternoon drinking this beer and at 7%, the alcohol might just sneak up on you.

Last bottle from Royal Mile, Des Moines.  What a treat this was....never wouldve guessed Id have to travel to Iowa to find this one.  Poured a dark reddish brown color...more red shone through in the light....minimal whitish head.   Aroma is big sweet malts, toffee-molasses sweet.  Maybe some dark fruits thrown in for good measure.   Flavor is similar, but does exhibit some nice hop bitterness...undetected early.  Flavor runs deep and sweet but surprises at the end with some decent bitterness.  Full bodied mouthfeel....I liked this one a lot.

Tap@Ølbaren. Tawney with a initially big golden brown head. The head slowly dissolves. the aroma is sweet with notes of fresh ryebread or mash. Complex big sweet taste with notes of roasted barky, bitternes and soft dilicate  aftertaste with a lingering bitter twist in the end.

Draught at Ølbaren.
Clear brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet aroma of dark bread and dried fruit.
Flavour of dried fruit, coffee and dark bread.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2006 From A Bottle.Deep ruby red in colour with a small head,aroma is of sweet malt,
taste is of big malt,sweetness,smoke and some roasted,the strength is well hidden.
This is very smooth,it looked after me,and I was grateful.
On tap. Dark brown with a great off white head. The aroma is sweet, with roasted malt, coffee and notes of smoke. Sweet, malty flavor with notes of roasted coffee and chocolate.

Clear red/brown, medium sized tan head. Farily sweet nose, some roast and chocolate, melanoidin. Sweet, soft, delicate flavor--chocolatey notes, slight bitterness, very well-balanced. 
Huge thanks to Saarlander for importing this one!

Bottled:
Aroma is sweet malty, alcoholic with light notes of coffee. Redish-blck color, bron creamy head. Flavor is sweet malty, nice notes of burnt malt, coffee notes. Sweet warm and pleasant.

Aroma rum and plum, dry coconut, chocolate, bread.  Looks: rusty garnet, murky, with shimmering red highlights.  No head.  Sweetness smell is subdued and not overly syrupy.  A bit like an old ale-type sweetness without the fruit overtones.  Slightly oxdized...Salty sardine-type whiffs.  Tastes: like a dark, rich, bread/muffin type thing.  Thick, heavy mouthfeel without being syrupy.  Not very sweet.  No noticeable alcohol.  Weak coffee on swallow.  Unlike any doppelbock I have had before.  Im having a hard time deciding between this and the Church Brew Non-Denominator.  Decadent but unexpected.  MANY THANKS TO NAT AND JIM!  =)

Aroma seems to be primarily chocolate, toasted coconut, nuts (Almond Joy?!) and rich caramel.  I like the aroma but it seems distinctly un-bockish.  It has a lot of the elements in there, but something is missing.  The head is, sadly, shortly lived and lacing isnt great either.  We tried several glasses but could get nothing to stick.  Still the body has a great hue to italways changing color depending on the lightIll call it dark amber for arguments sake.  The flavor starts sweet, but thin, and builds towards the end.  Rich tasting like very dark bread.  Body is medium and slick with average carbonation.  The bottom line is: A bit different than most doppelbocks Ive had (pretty varied style eh?) but not bad by a long shot.  A good head, maltier aroma, and thicker body would have made this a barn-burner.  Thanks Em!

Bottle.  Deep brown color with red ruby colors when backlit.  Smallish off-white head and good lacing.  Aroma is potently molasses with little notes of raisin.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Pleasantly sweet with a nice hop balance.  Little bits of hop bitterness in the finish.  Very nice, thanks Jeppe!!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2007 There is no other way to rate this other then a perfect beer. The true king of beers I must say. raisins and toffee in the aroma when it heats up, taste is much hoppier than I expected but the kick in the tongue is just awesome, this has the perfect combination of hops and malt. You can drink shiploads of this, words cant describe this....

Pours clear ruby brown with a medium tan head. Nice lace. Big toffee aroma with some chocolate and raisin notes. Sweet toffee, molasses, chocolate and raisins all the way through. Suprisingly not cloying though, quite well balanced. Medium-full bodied. Nice warming beer.

Bottle; Darkbrown/red with tight longlasting excellent looking head. Aroma of caramel and dried fruit. Flavor is sweet and caramelly with some subdued hops. A bit metallic. Mouthfeel is incredible smooth with relatively low carbonation.

Unfortunately the head disappeared on my beer within a couple of minutes. Otherwise a wonderful deep ruby color and a nice looking beer. Lots of malt flavors, dark and well balanced. Not too sweet like Salvator. Quite nice.

Deep tawny colour with a ruby tinge. Negligible carbonation. Sweet malt, plummy fruit and dark chocolate in the aroma. Silky, voluptuous mouthfeel.  Undeniably sweet and maybe just a little too sticky. Very rich flavours of licorice, caramel, molasses and more fruit.  Soft, but weighty. Solid malt backbone. Splendid stuff. Must be a benchmark dark German bock. 500ml bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2005 Bottle.  Chocolate, raisin, malt and tannic aroma - nice and subtle.  Dark amber-brown color - small head.  Creamy chocolate malt initial with a suprisingly mild tangy sweet middle and a mild astringent finish that is much milder than many other doppelbocks Ive tried.  A very complex palate.  A premiere doppelbock.

Bottle: Displays a rich mahogany hue that shines a beautiful ruby when seen against a bright light, large frothy light tan head and very good lace. The aroma screams out heavy malting with lots of caramel, toffee, and bready notes abound. Also detected some prune, aromatics, and cavendish tobacco notes as well. Moderate phenols and anise star like quality add to the nose. The taste starts as expected, sweet and roasty with just a nice counter balance of fruit twang and pepper for depth. Oh hey, I get some seasalt, cashew, apple and birchbier undertones too! Wonderful tasting without over dominating the palate. The feel is the one area I wish was better, I would like such a highly touted doppel to be richer and lush upon my tongue. This is a bit too fizzy. High marks for the mostly hidden alcohol content and the reason for the four rating "palate". Overall, while my rating is quite high, I still was left with a feeling of longing for something more, to have my "socks knocked off". This didnt do that, perhaps on tap it would have. Still, many thanks to my Secret Santa for hooking me up with this brew, Skål.

IslandHaole hooked me up with this treat!  Clear mahongany pour, small tan head.  Toffee, chocolate, sweet malts and caramel on the nose.  Flavor matches the nose initially, ends dry and sweet.  Feels a little thin, but coats well and has a creamy touch.  Outstanding.
This is so smooth and wellbalanced..A nice soft sweetness, turning into a coffeelike bitterness. Excellent brew, the best (Doppel)bock so far.., and probably one of the best beers in the world.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 What can I say? Perhaps one of the best beers I´ve ever had, color was beautiful, taste was great. Alcohol was there, but not too noticable. one of my best beers of all time! Balanced, balanced, balanced!
2010..Just had again..just as good!!
Bottled in Centimetre1, Wien. Dark brown red colour with big head. Licorice flavours emerge from  a dry hard sharp base. Nutty alcohol notes tire the palate.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2005 I was thrilled to get this beer all the way from Germany courtesy of my girlfriends father.  Brewed by Monks in the Alps.  Pours a beasutifu deep brown with subtle reddish hues with a small but lasting head atop.  Aroma is of hazelnuts, chocolate, roasted malts.  Same in taste.  Excellent balance of sweetness, strength, alcohol, malt.  Feel in mouth is very good, if only slightly thin.  Overall, a fantastic beer.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 Thanks a lot to civforprez for sharing this gem! Thanks to civ for sharing another one of these beauties. Pours a great dark brown with red highlights. A thin yellowish head tops it. Aroma is apples with a roasted hazelnuts. Also an earthy and malty caramel. The taste is very well balanced. It has roasted peanuts, celery and syrup. Then as you drink, you get roasted toffee and little sweetness. The finish is slightly salty. Overall a very solid and excellent dopplebock. I tried this again at the Nooga 2005. Still a solid beer.

The quest for this beer has taken me through many years.  Firstly, this beer smells so malty, with hints of dough that make your nose want to stay sniffing the glass.  The beer poured a clear, deep amber/brown color with a thick off-white head.  The flavor was very balanced with a great maltiness.  The finish was great which made this beer even more outstanding.  This beer is truly worth a perfect score as it is now my favorite beer for the style and one of my all time favorites.  Well worth the wait and very highly recommended.
A very pleasant and easy-drinking beer, and very reasonably priced in Germany :)I cant remember many details about this one other than it was rather overwhelmingly good.

Many thanks to thedm for sharing some of this beer.  If you want a sad, sad story, ask him about his success at carrying bottles of this home with him from Germany.  Very redish amber color out of the bottle with a frothy tan head.  Incredibally malty nose, like malt syrup.  Strong malty sweetness with an almost smoked roast pork flavor with apples, dried fruit and deep caramel sweetness.  Full mouthfeel.  A truely wonderful beer.

Thanks to Springslicker for sharing this one! Reddish brown, e-frickin-nourmous tan head. Very pleasent doughy, bready aroma, with hints of vanilla. Toasty flavor, with notes rye bread, pepper and maybe a bit of cedar?  Full bodied and light on the toungue at the same time. Nothing hints at its 7.2% alcohol. Very tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2010 Bottled.  A very dark coloured beer with a short lived tan coloured head.  The aroma has some roastiness in it and a little bit of tar.  The taste is full and rich.  Licquorice, malt loaf, roasted malt, oil and coal, and treacle all combine to give a really nice drinking experience.  Really good stuff!  Score 4.1Subsequent rating scored 4.0.   Score unaltered

Thanks to Indra for making this part of our recent trade!
First, this has a beautiful full head which is often missing or diminished in the Doppelbocks. Dark mahogany pour with a head of light tan. 
Rich malty nutty aroma that really invites a taste. Caramel and butterscotch. Full flavored, rich and malty yet avoids all aspects of being overly sweet or cloying - perfect balance. Rich and smooth with a medium body. Absolutely no alcohol presence. Not the best Doppelbock Ive had, but this one is getting there and if it were more widely available, it might easily take over the #1 spot. Very drinkable brew.

Fort Wayne Mead Tasting.  Very suprised to get to taste this one, and I thank Matt for the change to do so.  If the bottle could talk, it would first say "Drink Me!" and then tell you the sad story of how it made it to the States with barely the label on its back.  Poor little fella.  Anyway the beer...  Dark brown/red with a sizable  tan/offwhite head.  Very malty aroma with fruits in it as well.  A super tasting beer.  Malts, chocolate, and some dark fruits.  Super easy to drink.  A wonderful treat.

(on bottle) Big MOFO on the wood and chocolate sents here. The alcohol is well hidden for the nose, but with first sip, there´s a short kick of it, nice. Other impressions is nuts, nore chocolate, toffee and fat loads of dark malt. Underfermented beauty in motion. Grand beer for windy, grey, day in the fall when Bush is reellected, God forbid. With my salted herrings and rye bread, the alcohol wa a bit more dominant a some bitternes was brought in.

Dark reddish colour with large beige coloured head. Aroma is malty with some sweetness, notes of caramel, nuts and coffee. Flavor has some malty sweetness with some dark fruits. Some alcohol in the finish.

(bottle) Sweet, malty, toffeeish aroma, hints of prune and other dark fruits, bread and earth, also some faint wood and doughy yeast; fairly complex and unique character.  Mahogany color, clear, with a with a subsiding, light tan head.  Flavor is of course also primarily malty and sweet, perhaps very faintly vinous, with hints of dark toffee, plum, more faint earthiness and bready malt with just a brief appearance by the hop bitterness towards the finish, which is also very lightly roasty and chocolatey, perhaps some tobacco in the aftertaste.  Very full-flavored, to say the least.  Mouthfeel features some lively carbonation carrying the flavors rather well.  Body is medium-full.  Different in its flavor development and complexity.  Makes for a good nightcap or dessert choice, in which capacity it has already served a handful of nights.

Draft at the monastery in Andechs, Germany. Ivory head, transparent, good lacing and a reddish brown hue. Malty and caramel aroma and some light clove notes. Flavor was delicious-sweet, malty,caramel, some vinuous flavor, and a roasty aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel. A very, very good Dopplebock and well worth the trip to the monastery to get it fresh.

Poured a reddish brown color with a small thin, fluffy, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of dried fruits, sweet caramel and honey, light alcohol.  Sweet chocolate, caramel, light roastiness, musty cobwebs and light alcohol as well.  Creamy mouthfeel, this is a solid Doppelbock.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 Draught. Dark brown colour, nice light-brown head. Roasted, malty flavour. Slight coffee aftertaste. 5 4 7 3 16

Draught at the Kloster. Sweet malt aroma. Clear dark brown colour. Big stable creamy tan head. The flavour is quite sweet, has some malt syrup notes. Even seems as if it has a little sweet liquorice. It is wonderfully sweet, strong and warming. 7 4 7 4 18
A very good bock, it reminded me of the equally great gulden draak. The honney like taste really surprised me in a good manner.

Wow, a great dopplebock, probably the best in the world. Definately the best beer that I had while in Germany. Pours a lovely black crimson, loved this one because of the lower carbonation. Very very very good. Tastes sweet, great stuff.

On tap at the brewery. I drank a half liter of this, the darkest beer offered on the day of my visit. Aroma of roasted coffee. Big bubbles to the head. The guys pouring the stuff out of the giant kegs nearly throw the beer at you when you step up to get your mug. Not as strong as I had expected, but clearly the best "dunkel" beer that I had on the entire trip.

Sampled at the monastery.

Dark Ruby.

Big, hearty, meaty, strong and herbal nose with other whiffs of dark fruits and clove.

Front is smoke (slight) with many dark fruits. Notes of caramel, molasses and chocolate in the mid-palate. Plums, lots of plums on the lingering finish. Well this beer was excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2012 Caramel and berries stem from bready, nutty malts...A touch of earthy hop bitterness caps off the malt celebration...A most elegant Doppelbock, from aroma to finish; one which ages well too, oxidation being harmonious with its malt signature...
Very nice beer -- mild for its 7.1% abv.  Reminds me a bit of a porter -- perhaps the first doppelbock ive ever liked.  Wonderful nearly-chocolate aftertaste.

Abundantly malty aroma with notes of dark fruit (plum, prune, raisin), toasted malts. Clear, dark, amber-brown with ruby tones. Copious, fine-bubbled, tan head recedes to ample cover. Rich, thick malt flavour dominates. Progresses from sweet to lightly fruity (raisins, prunes, plums) to toasty to a long, moderately bitter, dry finish. Fine bubbles are engaging on the tongue while mouthfeel is soft yet full. Flavour and aroma open up to reveal its full majesty as it warms. Far more subtle and elegant than some other highly touted doppelbocks, this displays a full range of flavours without bludgeoning the tastebuds with any particular flavour. Sensational. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere.

Generous off-white head forms atop the dark brown body. Head is foamy, frothy, sticky, moderately lasting. Light ruby hints make the color seem complex. A truck of malt in the aroma. Various flavours of smoked fruits, red berries, blue berries, cherries, light smoke, light roast. Terrific integration of the aromatic components. Another sniff gave me mineralic or salty notes. Another hinted me toward bread. Yet another proposed candy sweetness almost approaching honey. If the aroma contained a truck of malt, its 2 trucks you have when sipping. Its intensity is pushed further although always staying in the subtlety grace as opposed to a celebrator. Incredible precision, every angle is well cut. Bolder than the aroma in its leathery expression. Quite dry overall. Nut skin, roasty and earthy light hops finish. Could last a little longer perhaps. It really tastes like fresh and clean water was used. Incredible malt depth they have there. Gets even better as it warms, close to a 10 as far as taste is concerned, I guess just a bit more length would nail it. Polite medium to full body, high carbonation is at the limit of being too much. Stellar doppelbock that grows on you sips after sips. New developments and happenings every time. 2 thumbs up to Stephen and his neighbor for this unique chance!
Tasty, sweet at first & a defined molasses flavor but with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Good head & good flavor going down. Very easy to drink!

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2004 Sweet, sticky caramel and molasses are all over this. Big, rich and sweet with tastes of chocolate and malt. A big bottle is about all I want, as this isnt the session beer for me but the taste is full bodied and big. So freakin smooth, like silk. Thanks BierKönig for this baby.

Wow. When you add in the atmosphere of the pub in Munchen and the great crowds and the great weather, this is a perfect five. Without all that, it is still an amazing, creamy dopplebock, unlike any other that I have ever tasted. I will make a trip back to Munich just for this one.

Bottle from the Offie, Leicester - the owner Muree raved about this beer and reckoned it was one of his all time faves. Translucent brown, thin head. Slightly medicinal aroma. Coffee flavour (quite thin, toffee also. Sweet, honey quality. Chest-warming, smooth, balanced. Very good, engaging beer.

On draft in Heidelberg in July 2003 (wasnt flowing at the brewery during our visit); also on draft at the brewery in 1985, and finally bottled (purchased at the brewery).  Full, malty-sweet, rich beer with big alcohol presence.  Complex flavors:  red fruit, berries, chocolate, coffee, caramel...  Each sip brings you closer to God.
Bottle bought in Germany. Pours brown  Brown with a tan head. Chocolate and malt in the aroma. The flavour is sweet, malty and chocolate and dried fruit/berries, with some evident alcohol. Very tasty

Bottle from Beers of Europe, 7.1% abv. Deep amber coloured, with creamy beige head, which left good lacing. Aroma is great and complex; sweet malts, banana, strawberry and lots more besides. Flavour is not disappointing after the aroma, sweet, malty, prunes, caramel and more. Smooth, moderately carbonated, medium to full bodied, with an excellent mouthfeel and a lightly bitter finish. The best doppelbock Ive tried.

A bottle procured for me by Dave, a loyal customer at my restaurant/bar, who has recently been bringing German gems back from business trips for me. All hail Dave!
Appearance: partially clear, dark ruby hue, an enigmatic appearance, really, clear here, dark there, obtuse in places, with a lovely, lush layer of pale, tanned foam standing guard on top.
Aroma: caramel & spice, soft & creamy, lightly toasted, with subtle fruit.
Taste: luscious fruit proclaims itself at the onset, a beautiful blend of grape, cherry, berry, & more, supported by a warm, generous malt bill.
More flavors interject as we continue, raisins, figs, chocolate climbs aboard, too, for a spell, contributing a subtle, sensuous cocoa feel all over the palate. 
Sublime, really.
This mere 7.1% ABV doppelbock only peeps up the tiniest bit in alcohol feel, so smooth it is, so rich with flavor, not harsh, nor brash, mellow, cool, yet bold with flavor, getting winey-er and winey-er in taste as we go.
Got to hand it to the monks at Andesch, for they are gentle, benevolent geniuses, and those who know their work are doubly blessed!

UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 (Rerate 27.4.2007, prev 8-4-7-4-16) Dark amber color, little beige head. Chocolate, nuts, toffee, grains and slight alcohol in aroma, this was as good as I remembered from the first time. Medium to full bodied. Strong chocolate in flavor, nuts, sweet caramel, even some vinous tones and mild alcohol there also with some roastiness. Aftertaste has nice warmnig alcohol with lasting nutty tones and chocolate. Excellent beer, still maybe slightly too sweet.

On tap in Wiesbaden. Beer was a dark ruby color with a thick, foamy head. Sweet smell of caramel, malt, and fruit. Body was thin and seemed watered down. Low carbonation. Really sweet caramel & honey, but balanced bitterness.  Finished dry and clean. Second mug tasted better.

Dark caramel body with a thick small head. Malty aroma with sweet roasted tones. Sweet fruity and honey notes on the first mouth impression developing into malt and hops. Low carbonation. Powerful but not overwhelming, the alcohol is well hidden. A little marvel !

Thanks to my friend Vince for sharing but also to his in-laws for bringing this back from their trip to Germany. Ruby colored brown body. Small tan head. Aroma is rich with sweetened malt, caramel, fruits, and I could swear I smelled grape bubblegum. Taste is equally filling withmore sweetened malts, caramel, some lighter fruit notes, a splash or two of brown sugar and faint grassy hops. Mouthfeel is full and rich while being mildly carbonated. Some slight alcohol warming as well. Finish is much the same as the taste - more malt and caramel. Damn good beer!
Dark amber color, sweet malty aroma caramel taste, full body, sweet dry finish.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2004 pours a nice red color with hints of brown and a light tan head. good clarity for sauch a dark beer aroma is very sweet ans slightysmokey.  the taste is quite complex,  strong malt backbone with dark fruit, roasted, smokey flavors.  long lasting finish.  i general i am not a dopplebock fan, except for celebrator, but this is not so bad, the more i drink the more i like.  i taste liqourice on the end. with a nice residual sweetness.
Ruby colour. Good head. Malty, sweet-ish aroma with lots of marzipan and a touch of smoke. Full-bodied, sweet flaviour with notes of blackcurrant and liquorce. Warming alcohol in the finish.

3/13/04.  Poured out of 500 mL bottle, shared at Pizza Port 12-Hour Belgian Festival 04 courtesy of jcalabre on RateBeer 3/13/04.  A dark brown red, mostly transparent with a red edge.  Head is disappointingly little, lingering on the edges with fast, blotchy lacing.  Still a pretty good-looking doppelbock.  Aroma is great-- very rich, complex autumnal malts.  Flavor is full, dark, and delicious.  A very balanced blend of roasted wood, grain, smoky fruitiness, and dark raisin.  Surprised at the roast in here, but its simply delicious.  Body is full and a bit dry.  Finishes long and malty, rich and swirling with compelxity.

Wow, Delicious! Given to me by my friend who recently went to Germany. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick off-white head. Aroma is roasty and woody. Taste is very sweet/syrupy with caramel malt, some hops and notes of dark fruits, wood, chocolate and smokiness. Very well balanced. Mouthfeel is very full, round and creamy. Highly recommended!
UPDATED: JUL 11, 2004 mahogany with orange tints around edges.  begins bitter and rich with caramel and malt flavors.   rich aftertaste that is slightly sweet
Reddish Coloring. Small Head.  Malt. Hops.  Sweet.  Fairly complex.  Damn fine beer....worth trying.

Very dark chestnut beer, slim dark-yellow head. Very bready nose, with aroma of dark brown candi sugar. Bit of pine as well. Great taste - bitterish, woody taste, balanced between hops and dark malts, superposed on a sweeter, malty and sugar-syrupy base. Well bodied, slick, very slight acidity. Classic beer. The "sugar syrup" description doesnt do it right - it is correct however, and it tastes good all the same.

On tap at Andechser am Dom in Munich. Dark brown with a large head and lots of lace. Nice rich malty aroma with tones of raisin and fig. Flavor is muc the same, slighlty sweet, quite malty tones of fig, raisin, and dark fruits. Not as rich as Celebrator, but more complex
Bottled(500ml). -dark ruby coloured with medium pale brown head, caramel and toffish aroma with roasted texture, nice bittersweet finish
May have had an off bottle. Mainly smokey and malty. Look forward to trying again.

Could be the best beer Ive ever quaffed.  Maybe cause it was at their 500 yr old bierstube and came from a wooden keg.  Was I dreaming?  Perfect balance of malt, hops and alcohol. Deep brown-red with white, lingering head. Lingering complexity.  Flavor of anise, toffee, and cocoa.  Round as an onion dome.

Pours a nice, dark, ruby color with very little head.  Aroma has a little malt to it, but it doesnt appear to be very fragrant.  The flavor is loaded with malt and has the Grape Nuts taste going on.  A little molasses as well.  The alcohol is hidden, but it comes back to bite you in the end.  Wonderfully balanced and tastes fantastic.

This is Bavaria in the wintertime! Snow coated mountains and warm and cozy Bierstubens.
Red to dark brown opaque color with the most beautiful medium creamy white head.
Roasted malts hit my nostrils immediately, with some notes of nuts, molasses, sweetness, honey and a nice level of alcohol.
Ver complex flavor, tons of maltiness, honey, sweetness and a very nice bittersweet ending. After that you can feel the warmth from the alcohol spreading in your stomach. This beer is beautiful and very balanced! Lucily i got a whole case!
Beautyful dark golden color with a good creamy head. It has a fruity aroma and taste. The aftertaste is mild and sweet. Simply a wonderful beer.

A symphony based on a few well orchestrated notes. Nothing brash. Nothing bowling me over. Not a cacophony, but a clear chord that diminished softly. Had a hard time leaving all the mentions of greatness behind. Probably made me an even harsher judge than I would have been. At first I thought it was good, but maybe not THAT good. The more I drank it, the more I thought all the elements were in unison. Thank you once again Pive for bringing this my way. And Chad, I for one am very happy that it's NOT like Celebrator.
Bottle.  Thin and way too weak for its reputation and style...this used to be a top 10 beer!?  Light brown, and like a watered-down Celebrator D-Bock.  That's all I've got to say.
A bit malty... Both in aroma and taste... Really like this to a great beer night !!!!
An all round enjoyable beer.Good in every department,but lacking a strong aroma.It´s difficult to describe the taste but i bloody well enjoyed it.I recommend this brew!

This beer was sampled at the 12 Hour Belgian Beer Festival 2004 thanks to jcalabre. This beer pours a clear red and brown color which dominates the hue. It left a thin white head which clung to the sides of the glass very valiantly. The aroma was very sweet and delectable. Heavy malts, honey, vanillas and raisins..just wonderful. The taste is sweet honey and raisin malts with slightly bittering fruits. And can we say HELLO MALT into the finish. Sweet and dry finish supplemented by vanilla and raisin throughout. This was one of the most throughly enjoyable dopplebocks EVER! I must have more!

Crystal clear copper/caramel with a thick, tan head.  Nice, malty aroma.  Nutty, sweet caramel, dark fruit, doughy bread, a bit of smoke and some chocolate.  Full, thick palate with a creamy smoothness which envelops the tongue in palapable joy.  The incredible sweet malt flavors are deep and rounded.  The fruit becomes a bit more predominate in the flavor, but it doesn't overpower the sweet caramel, toffee and chocolate.  A well-crafted and thoroughly enjoyable doppelbock.  As, or more, enjoyable as Celebrator.  Many thanks Jeppe!

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2005 re-rate without retaste. DAmn I put the numbers in wrong and just noticed in now..
Medium amber color. Small white head. Aroma is is very malty and sweet. A medium to full bodied dopplebock. Malts are nutty, fruity and sweet. Hops are slightly spicy. The sweet malt flavor shine in this beer. Extremely well balanced. Very smooth. Nice dopplebock. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

The Doppelbock pours with a deep red/amber body topped by a medium head with a good amount of lacing.  The aroma is incredible.  It's sweet, caramelly and malty with notes of sugary candy.  The flavor is sweet and malty with notes of sugary candy and butterscotch.  Medium to full bodied and smooth.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 So, my last experience with this was in early 2004.  Now, judging from my recent two draught samples in Bavaria (one at Andechser am Dom, in Munich, and one at the brewery), where I encountered overwhelming tartness in each, I can only surmise that either my palate has drastically changed, or something is awry at the brewery. In each .5 liter I ordered, of which I could only muster one sip, sourness and  a limp, frail body were prevalent. So poor, in fact, that I didnt even want to spend the time re-rating it. Their Jubiläumsbier Dunkel, which I tasted at the brewery, had a similar tartness albeit a bit more subdued. And the Spezial Hell was quite grainy and riddled with DMS. The Weissbier Hefetrüb, on the other hand,  was quite lovely, so who the hell knows whats going on. Was it a coincidence that three of the four beers I tasted were seriously flawed during my visit, or has this brewery changed for the worse?  I cannot imagine  the monks being happy with this stuff. Previous score was a 4.3, but the stuff now is undrinkable and my score has been adjusted accordingly.  Clear brown rust. Light tan head quickly fizzles into nothing. Luscious aromatic blend of tangy, roasted, toffeed malts with a suggestion of charred sugars, soft minerals, and alcohol-soaked bread. Subtle vinous, unsweetened chocolate, and raisin notes envelop the soft, leafy noble hop character. Miniscule carbonation. Melted sugar mouthfeel. Feathery roastiness briefly tames the charred sugar tingle before a stifling array of doughy, toasted, and chocolate maltiness. Succulent milk chocolate notes dominate toward the finish while the charred sugars and tangy malts continue to make their stamp on the palate. Intense firm black malts match the charred sugars with just enough pale malt husks and smoke   to temper the tingle. Roasted/sugared malt blend, creamed coffee, butter toffee and restrained herbal hop notes remain long after finish. Pretty remarkable brew, but, frankly, this fresh sample lacks a creamy body and the malt sweetness masks the sublime Hallertauer aromas and flavors.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: First had it from a friend assigned to the Washington Embassy.  My son brought some home from a recent deployment.  Idream of my next bottle

LiebeBier toted this (and other Andechsers) back from the Fatherland for us to try.  This acheives precisely what I want in doppelbock--a little fruit, big and never syrupy malt with a palate which supports it perfectly.  It is as good as they say.  It does, however, make me appreciate how good my local DeGroens Doppelbock is--a close call, actually, between the two for best of style.

Deep amber/red colored beer with a foamy tan head. Aroma is spicy of malt, fruit, raisins, prunes and a fine alcohol tone. Flavor is also quite spicy and heavy. Dark fruits, nuts and malt. Finish has a dry alcoholic bite. A great beer but not as complex as the Ayinger Doppelbock, the alcohol is too evident.

A strong but not overpowering dark beer.Complex flavour that lingers on your taste buds with a pleasant and lasting aftertaste. Malty without being too heavy.
One to make the long winter nights go much quicker.

1 Liter Draft at Andechs - Very, very dark brown, nearly black color. Huge white head. The thick cloudy head was over the top of the glass by at least an inch. Rich caramel, malty freshnes in the aroma. This beer caught me off guard a bit as I expected a strong blast of flavors. This is soft and has a very subtle complexity. Malt and fruit flavors present themselves well. Outstanding and a lot of fun. The only doppelbock I've had that I could, and did, drink all night.

Bottled. A gift from Pivo & Yogi. Thanks guys!! Tawny, sherry coloured body, with a super fine rising head. Drinks consistently from start to finish. Malty, yeasty, with ripe plums and sultanas. Nice late bitterness. Its the sort of beer that you sip not quaff.

This is a beer I won't forget any day soon! Beautiful deep chestnut brown colour and white head. HUGE maltiness (bread, nuts) in aroma as well as flavour. Full body. Long, warming (alcoholic) finish. Definitely an impressive doppelbock, albeit the alcohol can be a bit overwhelming...

'Twas a cold winters eve when I carefully strode across the icy parking lot to the base shoppette to get a sixer of Sam for the night. Much to my surprise, there were twenty or so cases of this on a display. Now I don't know much about Dunkels and have been disapointed by dark lagers before so I grabbed a single bottle to try it out. The next day I bought two cases! I think that tells you all you need to know! Well, that and it's rich and delicious, malts, fruits, more malts, hay, hazelnuts, more malts oh my this is good!

Bottled.
Dark amber with an offwhite head.
Warm, fruity and rather vinous.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2008 Bottle. Amber color, beige head. Toffee aroma, nuts, butter and cream. Chocolate flavor, metallic, creamy, hoppy notes.

Bottled. 
Ruby colour. Big malt presence in the aroma. Rich flavour of roasted malts with some fruitiness. Bitter ending.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Beautiful, crystal clear, ruby-colored lager. Large, fizzy, khaki-colored head with very good retention and mountainous lacework.
The aroma is all malt. Smells like a mash bin, clover honey, tofee and dark fruit.
The flavor is malty and sweet with just enough hops to make the sweet malt bearable. Theres a thin line, sometimes, between a great beer and a total drain pour. This one walks that razors edge and comes out smelling like a rose. This is not one of my favorite styles, but with this lagers  malt profile and semi-sweet finish, it should appeal to most everyone. Thanks to bierkonig for the bottle.

Bottled. Light brown head, medium persistant, reddish brown body, clear.
Strong maltiness, munich malt aroma, light yeasty (dough) weak fruity and spicy (plum, weak orange, cinnamon(?)), no hop aroma. Honey sweetness, rich malt flavor, full body, very long malt taste on the centre of the tongue, oily texture, weak bitterness, sticky mouthfell.
Thanks to jcalabre. This Doppelbock hangs well with the best of them, a slightly sweet roasted malt finishes with a subtle hops bite. Very nice.
Caramel, raisin and plum aroma. Dark brown color, beige head, very nice lace. Light roasted, butterscotch, sweet, hopbitter finish, smooth. Very good example of a doppelbock.
500ml bottle: Pours brown with thick tan head. Smoky with a roasty malt aroma. Has a mild alcohol bite in the finish. A good beer but not great.
UPDATED: MAY 11, 2005 A nice dark red color that pours a thick head.The head stays with the beer the whole time.This is the beer alot of u rave about and now i can see why.Definately a keeper
This is the beer your mother warned you about ... it's all you need for a meal.  Keep at it, you might figure out how the monks got the formula right.  Good with nothing but itself.

Rich malty aroma- raisins, molasses, sugar & chocolate. Muted hops, a little fruity. Dark copper brown clear with dissipating lacing tan head. Palate is medium watery body with med-high carb. Taste is light sweet and malty up front. Not as complex as I was expecting. Has decent hops presence to give a light fruity bitterness at the finish. Pleasant malt bitter after.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2005 Medium dark apperance, very malty and sweet. Complex taste.
This beer convinced me that doppelbocks are actually a good type of beer.
Re-rate: After having this about a dozen times, I´ve got to up my rating a bit, since this beer is heavenly. The smoothness and taste are extraordinary. I love it.
Huge aroma of molassis and nuts. The body on this is a thing of awe- so full and tasty, the mouth totally appreciates. Sugary and complex, with breadiness and nuttiness. Slighly bitter. Great beer.

Light amber. Medium sized head. Aroma displays,toffee,nuts, slightly toasty. Mouthfeel is creamy,clean,and coating(without being thick). Nutty,bready,fig,toast,flavors. Finish is sweet,with quite a bit of hop. Lingering finish displays clean,chocolate and roasted cereal flavors. Probably not thick enough for some,but cleaner than any other Doppel I've had,with alcohol perfectly hidden.The more it warms and loses carbonation,the more flavorful and smoother it becomes. I could easily drink more than one bottle of this in a sitting.Excellent!

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2005 Well I must say I was somewhat disappointed. I was expecting something great, but I guess it was still good. Very clear deep red-brown colour, but poor head retention (which was certainly not what I was expecting.) Aroma was quite malty, with a touch of honey, roasted malts (surprisingly) and slight alcohol. Flavour was malty (though not as malty as I was expecting) with a fair bit of dark malt character and quite a strong bitterness. I was expecting something like a really malty dunkel on steroids, but instead this beer was less malty and more roasty and bitter than expected. (Stupid comment about Salvator removed)  Well, I thought that perhaps the bottle I had in Melbourne had been mishandled , but I had it on tap at the Andechs outlet in Nürnberg and it was basically exactly the same. Its OK, but too roasty and alcoholic and not malty enough. My mate loved it though - it was the only beer on our trip that he finished before me!
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2004 Nice dark color with a good head. The taste is very a very smooth, strong malty taste. Very nice bock indeed.

Caramel colored, tan head, a slight bit 
lighter in appearance than I expected.  
Glorious malty aroma.  Smooth and strong 
taste.  Caramel flavor throughout with a little
kick of alcohol in the finish.  Good beer.

6/20/03, draft, Berlin.  Clear amber-brown with a thick, tan head.  Leaves beautiful lacing as the head dissipates.  Mild malty aroma with hints of chocolate.  Rich roasted malty flavor, figs and noticible alcohol.  Wonderful lingering fruity finish.  Smooth, almost syrupy palate, lightly carbonated and rolls around the mouth easily.  Got even better as it warmed - very good beer!

Copper brown hued with a thin coating of lacey eggshell head.  Thick sweet caramel and roasted toffee aroma.  Body is syrupy sweet and complex with a mellow chocolate chip cookie dough flavor.  Reminds me a lot of celebrator, but not as dark.  Very smooth and hides its alcohol very well.  Thanks Yogibeera!
Light yeasty and some molasses. No head almost. Cloudy. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Couldn't find anything special.

Very nice.  Sort of a weak aroma with a raisiny, nutty, complex taste, but the alcohol of 7.1% was more noticeable to me than in the Ayinger Celebrator Dopplebock.  Also, I thought the Andechser was a bit lighter bodied than I'd have liked.  Good, though.

Dark ruby/caramel in appearance with a thin head.  Rich malty aroma and a silky, smooth mouthfeel.  Smoke, woody, nuts with a dryness to the finish.  Alcohol pokes through slightly.  A wonderful lager.

(o,5 ltr Bottle) Pours a thin, quick dissipating, white head and a beautifully contrasting deep reddish-brown body. Lightly carbonated. Stong caramel nose... Sweet malt. Pronounced sweet malt, cocoa and a slight syrup sweetness in the finish. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Small light brown head. Dark ruby-red body. Superb malt in aroma and taste, but imo lacks complexity and is disturbed by a little alcoholic palate. Nicely balanced. A nice doppelbock though Ive bought several cases of this by now and find it less great than I did at first.

A deep red beer with a small fast disappearing head. It has a very sweet aroma with notes of alcohol and rowan berries. It has a very powerful bock taste with lots of sweetness, rowan berries, and notes of alcohol. But it is a little flat. It has a good palate. It's very much like Carlsberg now discontiued Semper Ardens Bock.
This beer is a work of art. Typically, I'm not big on lagers, but this Doppelbock is great. Wonderful maltiness, this is simply a world class beer that any beer geek/snob needs to try. Thanks, Bob

great beer. dark , malty,potent and stil a smooth easy drinking  beverage.
the malt character is outstanding. caramel, toffee, smome. smoothpalate withlight carbonation.
my pick for best lager beer.

Caramel and sweet malt aroma, chestnut, small toffee head, continuous stream of bubbles. Lovely bitter malt flavour, almonds as well. Amazingly smooth, talk about balanced! Sensational. Thank You Yogi_Beera.

poured a transparent ruby gleam wearing a thin blanket of suds..aroma had hints of cola, nuts, chocolate fudge, and smoke..very flavorful mix of chocolate, caramel, salty roasted peanuts, vanilla coke, a little alcohol..mouthfeel is semi-syrupy but chewy..pretty damn sweet also..its good for a doppelbock..which isnt my style..
Malty, carmel aroma and flavor.  Both the aroma and flavor are powerful.  Sweet, a little syrupy,chewy, its what I'd hope for every time I'm offered a Dobblebock.
One of the best Dopplebocks in the world. Roasty, chocolate, and smooth a delicious beer. A must try when in Munich.
user_location: 4800+ Miles from Munich,near UBW, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 11, 2003 Sweet, burned malty nose. Appearance is okay; clear brown/red coloured with a frothy head, quickly gone. Taste is sweet, burned malts, perhaps some fruits are there and some hop. Well-balanced beer. Palate is malty dry. This is definately a good beer, but not that good.

Dark brown pour with a tan head.Nose is malty and hints at toasted whole grain bread.First sip reveals a slight acidity with sweet ripe fruit. Excellent balance, full bodied with a rich malty flavor what more could you ask for. Thanks to madsberg for the chance to try this great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2004 Original rating from memory:
What else can I say but, the best beer I have ever had! Small fine bubbles, heavy flavor, full bodied, no foul after taste or bitterness. This brew is extremely smooth. Im Himmel gibt es kein bier! Darum trinken vir es heir! Translation: In Heaven there is no beer! That is why we drink Andechs here! 
10-5-10-5-20 Perfect Score!

New rating from the monastery correcting my previous sin:
The DM & Hotstuffs European Honeymoon trip beer number 67. This draft brew from the monastery in Andechs Germany poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized off-white colored mostly diminishing bubbles that diminish then linger around for a long time.  The head left behind a semi-transparent dark caramel ruby red brown colored body with no visible carbonation.  The aroma contained notes of brown and mild caramel malts.  I wished the aroma were stronger, but alas it was not.  The mouth feel was initially very smooth mildly tingly and lingered in the finished then goes away leaving a nice caramel malt lingering aftertaste. The flavor contained a nice mix of smooth brown malts and caramel malts that leave a mild tingly sensation on the sides of the tongue.  Still a wonderful beer and my all-time favorite because of the memories it brings back.  Simply a wonderful must have beer!  Excellent!  7-5-9-5-19

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 2013-03-03, bb 17 02 06, possibly 8 years old, 7-5-7-3-15=37It pours a beautiful dark brown color with generous creamy head. The oxidization in the aroma and flavor is moderate; the aroma is mild; the flavor portraits a good mix of dark caramel and chocolate; the bitterness is fading; it still has a good body structure and a soft and lean mouthfeel; as often happens, the final has some roasted nuts.Still very good.2010-10-27, bb 2011-03-29, possibly 7 months old, 7-5-7-3-14=36Dark mahogany color; generous creamy head. Aroma of dark caramel, mild, a bit oxidized. Good body strength; the flavor is quite malty, even if there is a dominance of caramel and light roasted malts, also with a nutty touch; the final shows more the roasted malts than the malt and the body is a bit drier, therefore not resulting as an exceptional beer.2003-01-20, 8-5-9-5-18=45Brown, dark amber color with ruby shades; beautiful, generous, thick creamy head.Malt aroma, sweetish, very light Madeira; aroma typical of Dunkles.Sweet, loads of malt, balanced by the bitterness only at the end. Solid, absolutely well balanced, powerful, malty, aromatic hop at the end.Undoubtedly one of the best bottled German beers.

The same color as the old penny at the bottom of the fountain at the mall.   Nice aroma for a Doppel (most smell like dumpster-juice to me), but I detected that awful sweet stench as it warmed.  Served cold, it was tasty and had a nice alcohol presence (needed to even the sweetness).  Not a top fifty in my opinion, but it was fun searching for it.  Don't let it get warm, for it turns to garbage.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 Jan, 2003 Drag me round the school yard and dump me in the garbage bin. I got the flavours, yes - sweet licorice for sure, and some farmyard stuff as well, still clinging to my boots, but I failed to hear the choir singing. Lager is lager is lager. The dark stuff tastes better than the light stuff, and I do prefer it, but at the end of the glass it is still a thin watery substance that doesnt do for the mouth, the heart, the soul and the limp biscuit that passes itself off as manhood, what ale does. This was as tasty a lager as Ive had - full marks for that - but the flavours were divorced at gunpoint from the wimpy pink carnation body mincing around the catwalk with its bum sticking out. The flavours were screaming for a hunky ale body to cling to - something decent and substantial like a Volvo or a Jaguar rather than the moped with the fake leopard skin seat which its got. This is Arnold Schwarzenegger riding a thin pink moped, and he dont look happy, and it aint very pretty. Now stop fooling about and give me a Stout. [2.4]
June, 2004 Ok. I tried this again. I didnt actually remember it was this one I had previously drunk. I bought a few dunkels to get to grips with this dark lager. I have yet to appreciate the style fully, but this one - the last of the bunch - did sit more comfortably with me than the previous examples. The flavour is all there, and the body - after having got accustomed to dark lagers - while light, is not entirely disfunctional. [3.0]
Aug, 2006 GBBF 7.5% abv.  Malty, dark and very, very sweet. Some cardboard. I couldnt drink much of this. [2.3]
I spent years in Germany and I love this beer. where can I find this beer in USA?

Finally my bro-in-law came through for christmas got me some very special brews this being the first on the block for rating. nice creamy head ,dark brown in color with sweet malty aroma,slight chocolate flavor with some licorice.after taste was the same .they masked the alcohol well was unable to detect any.Well made brew
this is the beer God serves in heaven....
Long lasting head, malty coffee aroma, strong yet complex hoppy/coffee flavour.  A very good beer, worthy of its status.
Sweet and roasty, but easy to drink. Very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2003 Dark ruby colour with a nice offwhite head.The first thing that comes to my mind smellng the beer is plums, and lots of them. The taste is caramel, plums and a pleasant touch of alcahol.This is a wellbalanced and smooth drink. Has a nice bitter taste in the end. Try it, and you won"t be dissappointed.
Deep Ruby and copper color, looks Great in my glass. Malty, Caramel,Creamy and the hops are there. Thanks R. W. for sending me this one, it was truly delicious, Highly Recommended !
hofmark aroma of sweet hay and some mars bar. fabulously thick, fizzy blood texture. some soy sauce and rye does not go too far. finishes very softly.

all right all right after 2 years of wondering whether i vastly underappreciated this, i had it again and yes, it´s true, i did. it´s one of the best looking beers i have had the pleasure to behold, which would have been lost on me the first time because i had it in the dark. beautiful clear mahogany, with excellent frothy head. similarly, the intense cognac and burnt rubber smells would have been wasted on me cause there was smoke from a bbq gone horribly wrong blowing in all of my (facial) orifices the first time round. malt flavours are hugely rich, round and fat, with just the right amount of hops to balance. i kept expecting it to be too sweet but it held it all in. very good stuff.
UPDATED: JAN 28, 2003 Very well-balanced beer. One if the better bocks I've tried. A pretty malty palate and nice dark, beautiful colour.

A deep copper/ruby color. Clear with a light tan head with lots of sticky lace. Tremendous nose of deep, rich doughy malts,caramel, touch of smoke and hallertau hops? Reminicent of a fresh wort. Medium bodied, smooth, rather creamy, with a malt profile unlike any other I have encountered. Luscious rich, bready, dark  malts bombard the mouth along with burnt caramel, pinches of spicy hops and finishing a bit dry due to the alcohol poking through just a bit, just as it should IMO. World class gentleman.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2003 Malty aroma, somewhat roasted, raisins and pepper. Malty flavor with licorice, raisins, plum, coffee. Hint of metal. Thick mouthfeel.

Perhaps my favorite beer moment ever. Sitting on the patio outside of the cloisters beer hall with the beautiful German country side streched out before me and fraternie as we quoff steins of this glorious brew. Just loads and loads of malt in this one. It manages to be wonderfully sweet without being cloying. Better than Ayinger.
not bad and not as complex as say celebrator or maximator i found this beer to be a let down when i tried it at the cloister when i heard so much about it before i even tried it
Beautiful dark appearance, with a very pleasant aroma. All kinds of flavors arise in it! Easy to drink. Outstanding beer indeed!

This was an elixir.  The flavor balance was fascinating--you get the savory flavors like caramel, chocalte, roasted nuts, and yet you also get the fruity sweet flavors, like banana, strawberry, plum.  Such complexity.  And of course, as it warmed up, things changed, making it all so much fun to drink.  Overall, it had all the flavor complexity (and many other similarities) of a Belgian dubbel, but just slightly less airiness to it.  No beer can be perfect.  The perfect beer for me might be the median point between this and the Traquair Jacobite.
Sweet, roasty, coffeish, powerful. This is my kind of beer for sure. Almost as good as Hancock Old Gambrinus Dark.

Brown with a tinge of red in colour, initially large head, fading to a small head with a little lace. Sweet malt nose, with a bit of a caramelly scent. Sweet at the start (caramel), leading to a roasty malt flavour, and slight hoppy bitterness. I couldnt help but think sometimes that the alcohol came through in the flavour abit, but it wasnt something that really worried me, i guess im being a bit picky.

a bit fruity in smell...for a doppelbock.  dark color but not dark enough.  good malty taste with definite alcohol presence.  still find Schwarzenberger the best doppelbock. unfortunantly it is only distributed on a small part of germany.  so i may be the only one.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003   Wow! Had it at the monastery along with a great meal and it totally hit the spot. Malts are of sweet fruit which slowly develop into chocolate and join forces for a blast of flavor in the finish. My new favorite dopplebock.
Sweet burnt aroma, creamy light brown head,sweet malty flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2004 Medium dark clear brown with creamy foam that drops to resinous arabesques. Looks outstanding in the glass as I wait for the liquid temperature to reach 55 degrees. Sweet aromas of carmel, a cobbler's shop, trace acetic acid. Madeira, nutty cocoa, anise. A very clean, dry though creamy feel. The finish is a long, clean licorice bitter -- very unique though not altogether amazing. The 7.1 goes down easy. I will have an Andechser on the plaza in the picture on the back of the bottle some day. Vielen dank, Pivo und Yogi_Beera !

The aroma reminds me of some candy I had as a child. There is also the smell of port wine in this dark coca cola coloured beer. There is some sweetness in the taste but the finish is dry. A german quality beer.

Dark cola and brandy brown with medium fading brown head. Coffee, burnt candy, malt, port wine, liquorice and honey aromas. Medium body and creamy smooth, not too sweet, palate with a dry crisp lifting finish. An elegant and sophisticated beer.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2003 This was one of my first rated beers on Ratebeer given 8;4,10;5;18. Since then I had it many times again, only 1 Dollar a bottle, so I have to rerate it - I was so unsure the first time. Nice deep brown Bock , also hints of red with a thin sticky crown. Taste after malt and chocolate. Also Prunes. Spicey. It is smooth and fresh and gives a very nice fullmouth aftertaste. One of my favourite beers!

Tasted it again I realize how nice it is, that the Alcohol stays behind. It also has some smokey undertones.
A big, sweet, malty beer with an alcohol content to match.  One of my favourites.
I was backpacking through Germany and stumbled on this beer.  Good double bock, highly recommend.

What an awesome quaff for the day after Oktoberfest. Fresh out of the cask.  Outstanding malt and incredible smoothness.  Maybe the soccer match and pork hock lunch at the monistary bumped my rating up, but it was as close to perfect as it can get.

Rich, delectable and complex. The sweet malty
nose and deep carmel color make this beer enjoyable
even before the first sip. Well-balanced, and although
there is a strong alcohol component, this brew is
somehow delicate. Sophisticated. I can also recommend
taking the the S5 train from Munich to Herrsching,
walking up the hill to the monastery and enjoying
this on the patio.
Great BUT NOT the best
Awesome
Quite possibly the best beer Ive ever had.  Rich malty aroma with chewy malt flavor.  A meal in itself.  The absolute best doppelbock made.

An outstanding doppelbock. Delicious, big maltiness, loads of flavours, perfectly balanced. The Andechs cloister itself is well worth a visit, but a bit dangerous if you walk up the hill on a hot summers day and then try to cure your thirst with doppelbock...
One of my favorite Bock beers. awsome malty aroma and yet smooth. Be careful one of these too much and you will sleep like an angel.
You guys might think Im nuts, but I like this better than Celebrator.  What a blast of malt!  Big bold caramel and port in oak barrels.  Lovely.

Beautiful dark color.
Big malty base - a bit vineous, fresh hop finish....I am lost for words -  it simply has all the flavors you want in a doppelbock in a perfect blend.
Ok kill me for this ... the only german beer I got so far reminding the big irish black one ... and I dont know why !
Outstanding beer...really mild for a strong beer...a real find!
Grestest food, greatest beer.  Thank god we kept the cab drivers card and were able to get home.  Best place we went to in Germany.
M-m-malty rich.
dark ruby colour, beautiful head, aroma: roasted, caramel, chocolate; strong malt flavor, sweet, well structured
The atmoshphere at the Kloster is wonderful. The food is incredible. The beer is superb. This is Gods dopplebock.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Draft, Nurnberg AndechsMurky-brown.  Aroma of hearty German breadcrust and some toffeeish notes.  Very rich, syrupy with loads of breadcrusty notes.  Long.  Some burnt fruits in there, maybe even chocolate malt.  Some alcohol comes in late.  A top 5 doppelbock.
